I have heard some terrible news for mathematics and statistics at Macquarie University: 5 mathematicians and 4 statisticians (at levels B/C) are being let go. #TakeCare

- Nalini Joshi (@monsoon0)

It's not clear who is affected, but potentially the category theory group there is at risk.
Lvl B=Lecturer, Lvl C=Senior Lecturer, and this is Commonwealth-style Lecturers, so Assistant/Associate Professors in the US style.
These are permanent positions, too, not just adjuncts or similar.

I don't think any category theorists are at risk (they are all too senior), but of course it's bad for the department as a whole. (The danger to category theory at Macquarie would be someone leaving for greener pastures. Though let me be clear that I have no reason to think that is going to happen.)

Ivan Di Liberti said:

David Michael Roberts said:

https://twitter.com/monsoon0/status/1365134447079612419

It's not clear who is affected, but potentially the category theory group there is at risk.

In the case of Leichester, they claimed that in the MathDept they are aiming for ML and AI. Do we know anything about their reasons this time?

It's all about money. Which is of course the reason everywhere, but they don't seem to be making excuses in this case.

I don't think any category theorists are at risk (they are all too senior)

this in itself is a problem, if there is no pipeline of people that are up and coming. I remember when Richard, for instance, started there. It was great to see fresh, younger people coming in then, and look where he is today. There will be more intense competition now, and there is no middle-career block of people that will be the next generation, unless recruitment can happen.

But, fwiw, it's good to get some more concrete details.
Yes right now at Macquarie in CT there is no one career-stage-wise between Richard (now an Assoc Prof) and me (still a postdoc).
We have a new HoD who is pro CT (a nice change), but it's not certain he will survive the merger.

This is what happened in Montreal, according to Marta Bunge when I was inquiring about PhD possibilities 3ish years ago. The established CT researchers got old and had no one below them to foster new students and young researchers.
